attributes.name: Stadsarchief Rotterdam
attributes.history: The Rotterdam City Archives are one of the oldest archives of the country. On October 22, 1857  the Rotterdam city council appointed a committee that would manage the materials that were kept in the city hall near the cheese market. Not long after the first municipal archivist was appointed. After a short stay in the Schielandshuis the archives were brought to a building in the Mathenesserlaan in 1900. In 1998, the archive moved to its current home, the former National Automobile Central to Hofdijk 651.
attributes.holdings: The Rotterdam City Archives manage archives of both the government and companies, associations, churches, and other organizations. You will also find family archives and archives of more or less famous people.
attributes.openingTimes: The Rotterdam City Archives are open from Tuesday to Friday from 9am to 5pm.
attributes.conditions: Before visiting the Rotterdam City Archives for the first time it is required to to fill out a registration form. You will then receive a personal visitor number. Upon registration, you must present a valid ID.
attributes.accessibility:
It is a 15 minute walk from Rotterdam Central Station to the Rotterdam City 
Archives.

In the vicinity of the Rotterdam City archives are enough parking spots. However, between 9am and 11pm you do have to pay for your parking.
attributes.researchServices: The materials can be requested through the reading room computers or application notes no later than half an hour before closing. You can apply for up to six inventory or catalog numbers simultaneously. The pieces will be ready within 30 minutes.
attributes.reproductionServices: All records can be copied for a fee, unless the size or the state of the document, third party rights or restrictions on publiciation does not allow this.

attributes.name: Stadsarchief en Athenaeumbibliotheek Deventer
attributes.history:
Since the Middle Ages, the archive has not only preserved the written records of the work of the city council, but also the archives of many Deventer families, institutions, organisations, churches and companies. It not only forms the basis for a good administration of the municipality, but is also a source of first-hand knowledge of the history of the city and region.

In 1999, the organisations of the Municipal Archives and the Athenaeum Library were merged. In 2003, new integrated reception rooms and study rooms for archive and library visitors were built in the completely renovated Klooster 12 building. The Athenaeum Library was one of sixteen public libraries in the Netherlands with a scholarly support function under the name Plus Library.

In the Klooster it has a plastered gable with a dormer. It forms a good finish to the cloister complex, where it connects to Noordenbergstraat. XVII-XVIII.

Moreover, in 1997 the municipalities of New Ginneken, Prinsenbeek and Teteringen were also merged in Breda. Since June 18, 2007 the archives of the diocese of Breda are also housed in Breda.
attributes.holdings: The Stadsarchief Breda manages eight kilometers of archive, 1000 meters of books and magazines, over 400,000 photographs, negatives, prints and drawings, including film, video, and audio, such as 78 rpm records.
attributes.openingTimes: The Stadsarchief Breda is open from Tuesday to Thursday from 11am to 5pm and on Saturday from 11am to 2pm.
attributes.reproductionServices: It is allowed to take pictures of materials, provided that you do not use your flash. If the physical condition and the size of the collection permits, they may be copied. However, this must be authorized by one of staf of the reading room.

attributes.name: Stadsarchief Amsterdam
attributes.history: The Bazel, the building the Amsterdam City Archives resides in, was the most important work of the Dutch architect Karel de Bazel and was built from 1919 to 1926 as the head office of the Netherlands Trading Society. Later, the Algemene Bank Nederland - one of the main predecessors of ABN AMRO -  resided in the Bazel. In 1999 the city of Amsterdam bought the building and after a renovation the building was re-opened to house the Amsterdam City Archives on 7 August 2007.
attributes.records: The Amsterdam City Archives attempts to mirror the diversity of the potentional range of archives and collections in Amsterdam. This has lead to a policy of acquiring that not only focuses on archives from municipal services, but also private archives and collections. In this case one should not only think of paper documents, but also digital files such as webistes, photos, and advertising materials.
attributes.holdings: The City Archives holds 50 kilometers of archives, a historical topographic collection with millions of maps, drawings, and prints, a library and extensive sound, film and photo archives.
attributes.openingTimes: The Amsterdam City Archives is open from Tuesday to Friday from 10am to 5pm and on Saturday and Sunday from 12pm to 5pm. Do keep in mind that the reading room and the reproduction room are closed during the weekends and on holidays. This means that on these days no original materials can be requested nor is it possible to print photos or any other materials.
attributes.conditions: Anyone who wants to do research in the archives and collections of the City Archives is welcome in the reading room. All books and records can be used for free. However, all books and records have to stay in the archival institution. Before you can access the reading room you need to register at the reception in the hall.
attributes.accessibility:
The Amsterdam City Archives is accessible by tram from Central Station: lines 16 and 24 to Keizersgracht. Do note that car parking in the center can be difficult and probably very time consuming.

Wheelchair users are requested to report to the bookstore entrance or to the café-restaurant. Scootmobile users can use the entrance at Herengracht 482.
attributes.researchServices: If you have any questions about how you should start your research or you believe to have hit a dead end, you can consult the staff at the Information Center for advice. Staff members also help you decipher difficult readable documents, although they do not have time to read very elaborate texts.
attributes.reproductionServices: Most documents can be copied or digitally reproduced. Under certain conditions it is also allowed to make your own reproductions. All fees for reproduction services can be found [here](https://stadsarchief.amsterdam.nl/stadsarchief/praktische_informatie/tarieven/index.nl.html).

From the end of 1936 to 1982, the RKD was housed in the monumental building on the corner of Korte Vijverberg and Toernooiveld. The various departments, which had become dispersed over the years, were reunited and accommodated in the KB complex from 1982.

attributes.name: RHC Rijnstreek en Lopikerwaard
otherFormsOfName: Regionaal Historisch Centrum Rijnstreek en Lopikerwaard
attributes.history:
The RHC Rijnstreek Lopikerwaard has emerged from the Streekarchief Rijnstreek in April 1, 2008 and holds materials from the Hoogheemraadschap Stichtse Rijnlanden and the municipalities of Bodegraven-Reeuwijk, Lopik, Montfoort, Oudewater, Woerden and IJsselstein.

The history of the archive service itself goes back to 1972. At that time, the (then) South Holland municipalities of Woerden, Bodegraven, Reeuwijk and Driebruggen and the Groot-Waterschap of Woerden established the Streekarchivariaat Rijnstreek. It was located in the town hall of Woerden. Municipal redivisions and the merger of water boards into Hoogheemraadschap De Stichtse Rijnlanden increased the working area. In 1994, the municipality of Montfoort joined the joint arrangement. Finally, in 2008, the municipalities of IJsselstein, Lopik and Oudewater joined in, municipalities that until then had had their own archives. On this occasion the regional archive service was renamed the Regional Historic Centre Rijnstreek and Lopikerwaard.
attributes.holdings: The RHC Rijnstreek en Lopikerwaard currently manages more than 1100 different archives and collections of (former) municipalities, businesses, institutions, associations, foundations and individuals.
attributes.openingTimes: The RHC Rijnstreek Lopikerwaard is open from Monday to Friday from 9am to 4:30pm.
attributes.conditions: Before entering the reading room, it is necessary register at the staff of the reading room. When you first visit the reading room, you are asked to fill out a visitor card; on subsequent visits you can simply mention your name.
attributes.reproductionServices: If the material and the size of the materials allows it (as assessed by the study staff) photocopies can be made; larger quantities or printing large format may take some time. It is allowed to use a (digital) camera, without using flash. Scanning or reproducing the materials using your own equipment is not allowed.

attributes.name: Rijckheyt - Centrum voor Regionale Geschiedenis
attributes.history: The city archive of Heerlen, since 1924 the municipal archive of Heerlen, has become  Rijckheyt - Centrum voor Regionale Geschiedenis in April 2006. Rijckheyt is Middle Dutch for "treasure" or "treasury".
attributes.holdings: Rijckheyt - centrum voor Regionale Geschiedenis (or Center for Regional History is the repository of the municipality of Brunssum, the municipality Gulpen-Wittem, the municipality of Heerlen, the municipality of Simpelveld, and the municipality of Voerendaal. In addition, the archive provides management and availability of the historical archives of the municipality Nuth and its former municipalities.
attributes.openingTimes: Tuesday to Thursday by appointment only between 10 a.m. to 12 noon or 2 p.m. to 4 p.m.
attributes.conditions: Materials that want to be used on Saturday have to be requestoned on Thursday before 5pm.
attributes.accessibility: The amount of parking spaces in the direct vicinity of Rijckheyt are very limited. It is recommended to park your car in the parking garage at Uilestraat.

attributes.name: RHC Groninger Archieven
otherFormsOfName: Regionaal Historisch Centrum Groninger Archieven, Groninger Archieven
attributes.history: The RHC Groninger Archieven is the information center for the history of the city and province of Groningen.
attributes.holdings: The Groninger Archieven accommodate approximately 27 kilometers of documentation, the materials consist of photos, films, videos, sound recordings, newspapers, and maps. The Groninger Archieven are in the posssession of a vast collection of materials related to the Second World War in the province of Groningen. An introduction to Jews living in Groningen and the materials and literature related to this topic can be found on the [website](http://www.groningerarchieven.nl/historie/joden-in-groningen). Moreover, a [photo book](http://www.groningerarchieven.nl/algemeen/publicaties-2/fotoboek-groningen-40-45) which tells the story of Groningen during the occupation of the Nazis has been published by the Groninger Archives and contains unique photos from the archives.
attributes.openingTimes: The Groninger Archieven are open on Tuesday from 9am to 9 pm and from Wednesday to Friday from 9am to 5pm. The reading room is open on a number of Saturdays per year, for more details consult the [website](https://www.groningerarchieven.nl/over-ons/openingstijden).
attributes.conditions: Before entering the reading room of the Gronginer Archieven it is required to register with a valid passport of driver's license at the reception desk. After registration you will receive a archive pass with which you can register your visit.

attributes.name: Regionaal Historisch Centrum Eindhoven
attributes.history: The RHCe supervises the formation and management of archives and information management at municipalities in the Metropolitan Region of Eindhoven (Asten, Bergeijk, Best, Bladel, Cranendonck, Deurne, Eersel, Eindhoven, Geldrop-Mierlo, Heeze-Leende, Helmond, Laarbeek, Nuenen c.a., Oirschot, Reusel-de Mierden, Son en Breugel, Someren, Valkenswaard, Veldhoven and Waalre). Other public bodies also fall under the supervision of the RHCe. After twenty years, these authorities are legally obliged to transfer their archives to the archive storage facility. The RHCe ensures that the material is accessible to everyone, now and in the future.

attributes.name: Regionaal Archief Zutphen
attributes.history:
The Regional Archives Zutphen are located in three buildings in the Spiegelstraat. In the old medieval building the reading room is located. In the other rooms are offices, a dining room and a depot where 4.5 kilometres of records are stored.

In the spring of 1976 the City Archives settled in the buildings next to the the medieval building.In 1987, the municipality also purchased the medieval building in which two years later the reading room was opened.
attributes.generalContext: The Regionaal Archief Zutphen (RAZ) is one of the four pillars of the heritage of Zutphen and surroundings. Together with Archaeology, Heritage Conservation and the Stedelijk Museum Zutphen, it is dedicated to the management and preservation of tangible and intangible heritage. The archive manages the historical information of the municipalities Brummen, Lochem and Zutphen.
attributes.records: In addition to the archives of the municipalities the Regional Archives Zutphen also manage various archives and collections of individuals. These include archives of churches, businesses, associations, but also an old photo or diary of a person.
attributes.holdings: The Regional Archives Zutphen preserve and maintain the municipal archives of Zutphen, Brummen and Lochem, as well as the archives of local and regional churches, clubs, institutions, companies and other organizations. The 4.5 kilometers of documents, photos, maps, books and charters represent a large history of these three towns in Gelderland.
attributes.openingTimes: The Regional Archives Zutphen are open from Tuesday to Thursday from 9am to 5pm.
attributes.accessibility: The Regional Archives Zutphen is located approximately 5 minutes from the Zutphen train station.

otherFormsOfName: Streekarchivariaat Kromme Rijngebied en Utrechtse Heuvelrug
attributes.history: The Regionaal Archief Zuid-Utrecht (RAZU) is there for everyone who wants to know something about the history of the south of the province of Utrecht. The participating municipalities are: Bunnik, Houten, Rhenen, Utrechtse Heuvelrug, Vijfheerenlanden and Wijk bij Duurstede. The RAZU manages the rich historical archives and collections from and about these six municipalities.
attributes.openingTimes: The RAZU is open by appointment. You can call, email or fill in the form to make an appointment.

attributes.name: Regionaal Archief Rivierenland

attributes.holdings: The Regionaal Archief Rivierenland (RAR) manages approximately 1800 archives of very different type and age: the archives of the municipalities Buren, Culemborg, Geldermalsen, Maasdriel, Lower Betuwe Neerijnen, Tiel and Zaltbommel, the archives of many predecessors of the Rivierenland water board, the archives of companies, social institutions, associations, families and individuals. The oldest materials date from the 14th century, the youngest of the past few years.
attributes.openingTimes: The Regionaal Archief Rivierenland (RAR) is open from Tuesday to Friday from 9am to 4:30pm.

attributes.researchServices: Materials of the Regionaal Archief Rivierenland (RAR) can be used without reservation. attributes.name: Regionaal Archief Nijmegen
attributes.history: The Regional Archives of Nijmegen manage the archives of the municipalities of Beuningen, Druten, Heumen, Berg en Dal, Lingewaard, Nijmegen, West Maas en Waal, Wijchen and the Rivierenland Water Board.
attributes.holdings: The Regionaal Archief Nijmegen manages many documents related to the Second World War. Among others, these materials include diaries, newspaper articles, brochures, letters, postcards, photographs and other documents. Some of the topics of the documents are everyday life during the war, the resistance, the Holocaust, the bombing of 22 February, and the liberation.
attributes.openingTimes: The Regionaal Archief Nijmegen is open from Tuesday to Friday from 9am to 5pm, except on Thursdays when the building is open from 9am to 8pm.
attributes.conditions: Visitors who wish to access records after 5pm must request these documents before 5pm. It is also to digitally request the materials through the e-mail of the Regionaal Archief Nijmegen: hetarchief@nijmegen.nl.

attributes.name: Regionaal Archief Dordrecht
attributes.history: From 1 January, 2013 the Regional Archive of Dordrecht, Dordrecht Museum, Huis van Gijn and the Centrum Beeldende Kunst, merged into one organization for art, archives and history of the city of Dordrecht under the name of Dordrecht Museum.
attributes.records: Apart from government archives the Regional Archives of Dordrecht also manages private archives and collections of individuals and institutions.
attributes.holdings: Eight kilometers of archive material. It includes the widee and diverse collection of the Regional Archives of Dordrecht. In addition to printed material such as all newspapers from Dordrecht and an extensive library, there are hundreds of meters with handwritten documents on paper and parchment, the oldest piece dates from 1200.
attributes.openingTimes: The Regional Archive of Dordrecht is open from Tuesday to Friday from 11am to 5pm.
attributes.conditions:
In the reading of Regional Archives Dordrecht you can us the original records. The archive has an external repository. Therefore, original documents (if not digitized) need to  be requested in advance. This can be done at home via the website or in the reading room. It is not possible to make telephone requests for materials.

At the first visit to the reading room you receive, after showing a valid ID, a visitors number. With this number you can apply for personal records using the application system. If you do not have a visitor number  and want to apply for pieces from home, you can simply enter '12345' as your visitors number.
attributes.accessibility: The Regional Archive of Dordrecht located at a fifteen minute walking distance from the train station and a five minute walking distance from the parking lot on the Korte Kolfstraat 235.
attributes.reproductionServices: Copies on a plain copier (ie no book copier), can be made on site. More than ten copies or copies that can be copied to the book copier, will be sent home or can be picked up later in the study. The processing time of these orders is 10 working days. When the nature of the material allows it scans can be made. These can be put on a USB stick or be sent digitally after payment. Also, it is allowed to use your own camera without flash to make copies of the documents.
